name: 系統演化學
description: Phylogenetics explores how organisms, genes, and traits have evolved, and seeks to represent the history of life’s divergence through the use of phylogenetic trees. Phylogenetics has contributed to a wide variety of research particularly in the fields of systematics, biogeography (phylogeography), adaptive evolution and community structure. Lectures will emphasize the logical basis and computational principles of various tree-building algorithms and associated methods of hypothesis testing, as well as application of next-generation sequencing data in phylogenetic tree building. In general, this course will focus on the use, interpretation and methods of reconstructing evolutionary trees.
goals: To understand the logical basis and computational principles of various tree-building algorithms
To understand and perform hypothesis testing
To learn how to interpret evolutionary trees
syllabus:
1 Introduction and course organization

2 Introduction to phylogenetic analysis using genotyping and DNA sequences data

3  Molecular homology, multiple sequence alignments

4  Distance methods: models of nucleotide and protein evolution

5  Parsimony: tree length and other indices, molecular clock, substitution modeling testing,   tree-searching algorithms, consensus trees

6  Maximum likelihood theory and methods; Phylip, PAUP\*, RaxML, Garli, and Mesquite

7  Accuracy and performance of MP & ML; Assessment, Tree Confidence; Phylip and PAUP\*

8  Maximum likelihood theory and methods; Topology tests (Templeton, KH, SH, AU and SOWH tests)

9  Midterm examination

10  Bayesian methods; Introduction to MrBayes

11  Molecular divergence dating (1)

12  Molecular divergence dating (2)

13  Applications in phylogeography research (1)

14  Applications in phylogeography research (2)

15  Applications in adaptive evolution research (1)

16  Applications in adaptive evolution research (2)

17  Applications in community structure research

18  Final examination
